# Update button styles to new design (2025-11-17 23:06Z)

_**User (2025-11-16 21:29Z)**_

can you please go over all the routes, pages and components and update all the colored 'pill' style buttons on the site to conform to the new @AGENTS.md @AGENTS.md (20-26) 

---

_**Agent (model gemini-3-pro, mode Plan)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Updating Button Styles**

I'm currently focused on the button styles. I'm taking the new styling standard, as defined in `AGENTS.md`, and applying it to the colored "pill" buttons.  The base style is clear, and I'm looking at the hover state, aiming to build a solution that's both efficient and maintainable.


**Examining Button Implementation**

I'm now in the process of mapping the "pill" button implementations within the codebase. My focus is on the codebase files, in `src/components` and `src/app` directories, and identifying their current button styling. I'll need to figure out which classes will need adjustments. I need to make sure to search the `src/app/globals.css` file as well. After finding all instances, I'll be in a good place to start the plan of action.


</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Analyzing Button Styles**

I've been examining the CSS in `src/app/globals.css`, and I've zeroed in on the button styles, particularly lines 1073-1155. It looks like `.btn` is the base, and variants like `.btn-primary` build upon that. I am also currently working on understanding the existing button style.


**Refining Button Design**

I'm now integrating the new requirements into the button styles. I'm focusing on incorporating the Tailwind classes like `rounded-lg` and `hover:scale-110`. The challenge is how to best translate the hover effects and border styling into the existing CSS variable structure. I will have to ensure consistency and maintainability while making these changes.


**Exploring Button Usage**

I'm now investigating the actual usage of the button styles across the project. I'm focusing on identifying the use of the `.btn` and `btn-` classes, along with any direct Tailwind class applications on buttons. I've begun searching for `btn-primary`, `btn-success`, `btn-warning`, and potential `btn-danger` instances to establish the prevalence of existing style variations. I am also working on finding uses of the generic `<button>` tag with any Tailwind classes.


</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Pinpointing Stylesheets**

I've identified the primary styling rules for the buttons in `src/app/globals.css`. I'm seeing `.btn-primary`, `.btn-success`, and `.btn-warning` defined there. Also, I'm finding inline styles in certain page files, specifically within the `src/app/animals/[id]/page.tsx` file, which is something to address.


**Centralizing Button Styles**

I'm now focusing on standardizing the button styles. I've discovered pre-existing hover effects in various components, aligning with what I want. My current plan involves adjusting `src/app/globals.css` to centralize these base styles and the hover behaviors. I will modify existing button classes and introduce a `.btn-danger` class for consistency. I want to build a reusable component in the future.


**Defining Button Hover Effects**

I'm currently working to centralize the hover effects for each button variant. I'll add `transform: scale(1.1)`, `box-shadow: var(--shadow-md)`, and the specific border/background colors for each variant, like primary, success, and warning. I'll need to carefully review `src/app/globals.css` again for border colors. Additionally, I'll identify and remove conflicting or redundant inline styles found through the grep results.


**Incorporating Color Variables**

I'm now integrating specific color variables for hover and border effects. Based on the hex codes I extracted from `src/app/animals/[id]/page.tsx`, I'll define `--success-dark` as `#047857`, `--success-hover` as `#059669`, `--warning-dark` as `#b45309`, and `--warning-hover` as `#d97706`. These will be used for `.btn-success` and `.btn-warning` respectively to ensure consistency with existing page styles. My next step is incorporating these new variables into `src/app/globals.css`. I'll also double-check for potential conflicts or overlaps with existing variables.


**Analyzing Variable Consistency**

I'm now comparing the discovered variables with the hex codes found in various files. While the extracted colors are close, they don't seem like an exact match. I'm considering integrating these colors into `globals.css` directly or adding them as new variables to maintain complete consistency. I'll also review the context of the colors in `src/app/animals/[id]/page.tsx`, `src/components/customer/AssociatedAnimalsCard.tsx`, and `src/components/customer/CustomerInfoCard.tsx` as well.


</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Refactoring Buttons' Styles**

I've examined the button styles in `ConfirmationModal.tsx` and `ConfirmDialog.tsx`.  The plan is clear: migrate the inline styles in `ConfirmationModal.tsx` to consistent classes matching the styles in `ConfirmDialog.tsx`. This aims for stylistic uniformity in button elements across the application.


**Enhancing Button States**

I'm in the thick of refining button styles. I'm adding standard hover effects (scale-110, shadow-md) and border adjustments to `.btn-primary`, `.btn-success`, and `.btn-warning`. I've used hex codes from `page.tsx` for these hover effects, opting to define `--error` and a corresponding hover state for the `.btn-danger` variant as it's missing. I'm also ensuring `.btn-outline` aligns with the established transition and hover scale.


**Prioritizing Button Styles**

I've set my sights on the filled "pill" buttons initially, focusing on those first. I'll need to double-check the outline button styles, ensuring the scale effect is correctly applied. I'm formulating a plan to refactor components, with an emphasis on replacing inline styles with `.btn` classes. Starting with `src/app/animals/[id]/page.tsx`, I'll tackle this task incrementally and verify the changes across the application.


</details></think>
